questions.text: A 28 year old woman, G2 P1 L1 at 38 weeks gestation is seen in early labor. She has a history of cesarean section done 3 years ago for breech presentation. The obstetrician decides on a cesarean section. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a cesarean section in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Maternal Indications for Cesarean Delivery
  • Prior Cesarean Delivery: most common
  • Abnormal Placentation (Option A): Placenta previa and placenta accreta
  • Prior Classical Hysterotomy
  • Prior Uterine Incision Extension
  • Uterine Incision Dehiscence (Option B)
  • Prior Full-Thickness Myomectomy
  • Genital Tract Obstructive Mass
  • Invasive Cervical Cancer
  • Prior Trachelectomy
  • Permanent Cerclage
  • Prior Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery
  • Prior Significant Perineal Trauma
  • Pelvic Deformity
  • HSV or HIV Infection
  • Cardiac or Pulmonary Disease.
  • Cerebral Aneurysm or Arteriovenous Malformation: Increase the risk of a stroke
  • Pathology Requiring Concurrent Intraabdominal Surgery
  • Perimortem Cesarean Delivery

Selection criteria for TOLAC

Contraindications for TOLAC

One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar

Previous classical or inverted T shaped uterine incision

Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section

Previous more than two lower segment cesarean section

Pelvis adequate for fetus

Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD

Continued labor monitoring possible

Presence of other complications in pregnancy: obstetric ( malpresentation , pre-eclampsia , placenta previa) or medical

Availability of resources (anesthesia , blood transfusion) for emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of decision

Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC

Informed consent of the women

History of prior uterine rupture

questions.text: Which among the following statements on the first stage of labour is false?

options.label: C
options.text: The upper uterine segment contracts and the lower uterine segment dilates.

options.label: D
options.text: During contraction, maternal heart rate and systolic blood pressure increase.

questions.explanation:
Aspect of First Stage of Labour

Description

Onset
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions followed by the expulsion of blood-stained mucous(show) from the vagina.

Uterine Contractions
  • Painful, involuntary, and gradual increase in frequency and intensity.
  • Intervals between contractions shorten from approximately 10 minutes to as little as 1 minute or less.

Cervical Changes
  • Effacement (shortening and thinning of the cervix) and dilation (opening of the cervix up to 10 cm) occur progressively during labour.Effacement precedes dilation.

Distinct Uterine Segments
  • The upper segment contracts firmly.
  • The lower segment remains softer and passive to facilitate fetal descent.

Maternal Physiological Changes
  • Increased heart rate and systolic blood pressure during contractions; relaxation between contractions essential for uteroplacental blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following is an event in the second stage of labor?

options.label: D
options.text: Expulsion of blood-stained mucous per vagina(show)

questions.explanation:
Aspect of Second Stage of Labour

Description

Definition

  • Full dilatation of the cervix to expulsion of the fetus.

Pain and Intensity
  • Pain intensifies with contractions

Bearing Down Efforts
  • Voluntary expulsive efforts due to vaginal stretching by the presenting part (head).
  • Efforts should coincide with uterine contractions.
  • Sustained pushing beyond contractions is discouraged.

Membrane Status
  • Membranes may rupture with a gush of amniotic fluid either before or during the descent of the fetus.
  • Rarely, the baby may be born in the caul (intact membranes).

Descent of the Fetus
  • Head rotation also occurs.

Vulva

  • 'Crowning' of the head occurs when the widest part of the head stretches the vulval outlet.

questions.text: Given below is the instrument used in a procedure done in the second stage of labor. What is the most commonly performed type of this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.
  • It may not be suitable for all cases, depending on perineal anatomy.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Reduced risk of injury to the anal sphincter.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

Lateral/
Transverse
  • Potential for reducing the risk of severe perineal tears compared to midline.
  • Less disruption to perineal body alignment.
  • May be quicker to perform in some cases.
  • Higher risk of complications such as Bartholin's duct injury.
  • Increased likelihood of uneven wound healing.
  • Not preferred due to the potential for structural damage and poor cosmetic outcomes.

T-shaped
  • Potential for minimising anal sphincter injury.
  • May provide better vaginal opening in complex deliveries.
  • Less risk of perineal tear extension.
  • Complex to perform.
  • Likely to cause puckering and imperfect wound closure.
  • Not widely recommended due to the potential for postoperative complications and difficult repair.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 24 hours after a vaginal delivery with complaints of severe perineal pain and difficulty with bowel movements. Upon examination, a third-degree perineal tear is diagnosed. What is the not done as next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate repair of the tear
questions.explanation:
1

Positioning

Lithotomy position, clean the area.

2

Anaesthesia

Local infiltration with lignocaine, pudendal block, or regional/general anaesthesia.

3

Suturing steps
  1. Start with rectal and anal mucosa using No. 3-0 vicryl or PDS, interrupted sutures with knots inside.
  2. Suture rectal muscles and pararectal fascia with interrupted sutures using the same material.
  3. Reconstruct sphincter ani externus (EAS) with figure-of-eight stitch, support with additional interrupted sutures.
  4. Repair perineal muscles with interrupted No. 0 PDS or similar, and bury knots under superficial muscles.
  5. Close the vaginal wall and perineal skin with interrupted sutures.

4

Suture materials
  • External anal sphincter: PDS or vicryl.
  • Internal anal sphincter: Finer sutures like 3-0 PDS.

5

After care
  • Similar to post-episiotomy care.
  • Specific care for complete tear repairs:
    • Low-residue diet post-repair.
    • Lactulose to soften stools.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Pelvic floor exercises.
    • Follow-up at 6-12 weeks postpartum.
    • Further consultations for persistent incontinence.

6

Future Pregnancies
  • Institutional Delivery: Recommended for all women post-repair.
  • Vaginal Delivery: May be considered with or without an episiotomy.
  • Elective Caesarean: Recommended for women with symptoms or abnormal findings on endoanal ultrasound or anorectal manometry.

questions.text: Which among the following is the first-line uterotonic agent during labour?
questions.explanation:
Uterotonic Agent

Route

Uses

Contraindications

Ergometrine (0.25 mg)

 

Methylergometrine (0.2 mg)

IM
  • Used if oxytocin is unavailable.
  • It cannot be used for induction or augmentation (cause tetanic contractions)
  • Twin pregnancy
  • Organic heart disease
  • Preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  • Rh (-ve) female.

Carboprost

250 mcg i.m

AMTSL and PPH
  • Asthma.
  • Pulmonary hypertension.
  • Cardiac disease.

Misoprostol (PGE1)

600 mcg Rectally, orally, sublingually
  • Ripening of cervix.
  • Induction of labour.
  • AMTSL.
  • PPH Rx.
  • Previous cesarean section.

Carbetocin (analogue of oxytocin)

100 mcg i.v over 1 min
  • AMTSL
  • PPH
  • Longer half-life

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of early cord clamping?

A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with her second child at 38 weeks, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit due to decreased fetal movements. A cardiotocography (CTG) is performed, revealing a baseline fetal heart rate of 130 beats per minute with decelerations. These decelerations vary in shape, timing, and duration, often occurring independently of contractions and sometimes appearing as "V" or "W" shapes. Based on the CTG findings described, what is the most likely underlying cause?
Which perinatal outcome is more common in breech presentations than cephalic presentations, regardless of mode of delivery?
questions.explanation:
Category

Complications

Maternal
  • Increased risk of operative delivery (cesarean section or assisted vaginal delivery).
  • Increased risk of perineal trauma.
  • Prolonged labour.
  • Postpartum haemorrhage.
  • Pain and discomfort
  • Infection

Fetal
  • Umbilical cord prolapse.
  • Birth trauma, including head injuries (due to increased risk of head entrapment in vaginal delivery).
  • Hypoxic-ischemic injury due to cord compression or prolonged delivery.
  • Increased risk of birth defects or anomalies.

During Delivery
  • Shoulder dystocia (especially in breech extraction during vaginal delivery).
  • Delayed delivery of the aftercoming head (leading to potential birth asphyxia).
  • Increased risk of brachial plexus injuries.
  • Increased risk of fetal fractures (such as clavicle fractures).
  • Difficulty delivering the placenta (due to abnormal presentation).

questions.text: A 28 year old multiparous woman at 39 weeks gestation arrives at the labour and delivery unit in active labour. She is confirmed to have a frank breech presentation. Which of the following is NOT a prerequisite for proceeding with assisted breech extraction?

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is kept hydrated orally

questions.correct_answer: D. The patient is kept hydrated orally

questions.text: Match the following images of forceps with their names. 1. a. Simpson forceps 2. b. Piper forceps 3. c. Wrigley's forceps 4.​​​​​​​ d. Kielland forceps
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman at 41 weeks gestation comes to the labour and delivery room. On per vaginal examination, her BISHOP score is 9 and uterine contractions every 30 min. Artificial rupture of membranes is planned using the instrument shown in the image below. Which of the following is the instrument being used?
